attachments.title: [medium] Add Archidekt as a data feed

attachments.fallback:
Donald Miner commented on [medium] Add Archidekt as a data feed: "Explanation of how to do this from the Archidekt people:

To get a list of decks with a commander you can use the following endpoint along with query string parameters.

<https://archidekt.com/api/decks/cards/>

It returns a json that's paginated with a count field, a previous and next fields, and a results field. The results field is a list of deck objects that has a bunch of data, but what I imagine you'll mainly need is the id field as that will allow you to access an endpoint to view the cards in a deck. The query string parameters you'll likely need for the above endpoint are the following:

commanders - expects a comma separated list of commanders with quotes around each (ie: ?commanders="Chromium, the Mutable")
orderBy - you'll probably want to use the -created at to order to see the most recent decks, updatedAt is another option (ie: &orderBy=-createdAt)

So to use the endpoint to get all decks for Chromium, the Mutable, would look like:

<https://archidekt.com/api/decks/cards/?commanders=%22Chromium%2C%20the%20Mutable%22&orderBy=-createdAt>

Once you've gotten your deck ids from that endpoint to access a list of cards in a deck you can use the following endpoint replacing <DECK_ID> with the id of deck you'd like to fetch:

<https://archidekt.com/api/decks/<DECK_ID>/small/>

This returns a json object with a lot of deck information but you'll probably just want the cards field which contains a list of card objects with quantity and deck builder information and each of those objects contains a card field that contains actual card information such as the name field which I assume you'll need."
attachments.text:
Explanation of how to do this from the Archidekt people:

To get a list of decks with a commander you can use the following endpoint along with query string parameters.

<https://archidekt.com/api/decks/cards/>

It returns a json that's paginated with a count field, a previous and next fields, and a results field. The results field is a list of deck objects that has a bunch of data, but what I imagine you'll mainly need is the id field as that will allow you to access an endpoint to view the cards in a deck. The query string parameters you'll likely need for the above endpoint are the following:

commanders - expects a comma separated list of commanders with quotes around each (ie: ?commanders="Chromium, the Mutable")
orderBy - you'll probably want to use the -created at to order to see the most recent decks, updatedAt is another option (ie: &orderBy=-createdAt)

So to use the endpoint to get all decks for Chromium, the Mutable, would look like:

<https://archidekt.com/api/decks/cards/?commanders=%22Chromium%2C%20the%20Mutable%22&orderBy=-createdAt>

Once you've gotten your deck ids from that endpoint to access a list of cards in a deck you can use the following endpoint replacing <DECK_ID> with the id of deck you'd like to fetch:

<https://archidekt.com/api/decks/<DECK_ID>/small/>

This returns a json object with a lot of deck information but you'll probably just want the cards field which contains a list of card objects with quantity and deck builder information and each of those objects contains a card field that contains actual card information such as the name field which I assume you'll need.

attachments.fallback:
Donald Miner commented on [medium] Add Archidekt as a data feed: "To add a new data feed, we need a script like tappedout.py and deckstats.py which is in web.py. This model will likely be different because they are actually giving us a json endpoint and we don't have to scrape html.

After we have that script working, we need to add the scraping to allnightly.sh"
attachments.text:
To add a new data feed, we need a script like tappedout.py and deckstats.py which is in web.py. This model will likely be different because they are actually giving us a json endpoint and we don't have to scrape html.

After we have that script working, we need to add the scraping to allnightly.sh
